headline: BorgWarner Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd be happy to do that, and let me give you some commentary. Our view is -- yes, there will be the mid-cycle review, obviously. That's all planned. Our view based on the multiple different inputs we get is we're not anticipating significant adjustments o
componenttext: I'd be happy to do that, and let me give you some commentary. Our view is -- yes, there will be the mid-cycle review, obviously. That's all planned. Our view based on the multiple different inputs we get is we're not anticipating significant adjustments or change to the plan. I think there's going to be sure robust discussion. That's obviously even more robust with gas at less than $2 a gallon. So I think there'll be a discussion, but I think, significantly, changes I don't think are going to happen is our view of the world. So we think it's going to continue on as planned, frankly speaking. What we do see, which I alluded to in part of my comments, Pat, is there is absolutely a push for a spectrum of alternative types of powertrains. So we're not seeing people at all step away from advanced IC engines. That's absolutely front and center. There's a tremendous amount of activity and launches around advanced gas engines. But yet we see strong push for pure electrics, which we're right in the middle of and hybrids as well in the many different configurations of hybrids. So I think there's a general march towards execution of the standard, maybe with a few tweaks and each of the OEMs getting a suite or a spectrum of architectures that they can get to deliver on those numbers. And we're right in the middle of all of those architectures in discussions with them. So that's our view of how we see it right now, Pat.

I would now like to turn the call over to Ken Lamb,  VP of Investor Relations. Mr. Lamb, you may begin your conference.

headline: BorgWarner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Melissa. Good morning, and thank all of you for joining us. We issued our earnings release this morning at around 8:00 a.m. Eastern. It's posted on our website, borgwarner.com, on our Investor Relations homepage. A replay of today's conference
componenttext:
Thank you, Melissa. Good morning, and thank all of you for joining us. We issued our earnings release this morning at around 8:00 a.m. Eastern. It's posted on our website, borgwarner.com, on our Investor Relations homepage. A replay of today's conference call will be available through May 13. The dial-in number for that replay is (800) 585-8367. You'll need the conference ID, which is 77109071, or you can listen to the replay on our website.  
With regard to our Investor Relations calendar, we will be attending the following conferences between now and our next earnings release: the Wells Fargo Industrials Conference in New York on May 10; the Barclays America's Select Conference in London on May 18; the KeyBanc Automotive Industrial and Transportation Conference in Boston on June 1; Deutsche Bank Industrials Conference in Chicago on June 9; and the Citi Industrials Conference in Boston on June 14. 
Now back to today's earnings release. Before we begin, I need to inform you that during this call, we may make forward-looking statements, which involve risks and uncertainties as detailed in our 10-K. Our actual results may differ significantly from the matters discussed today. 
Now moving on to our results. James Verrier, President and CEO, will comment on the industry and provide a high-level overview of our result and expectations for the remainder of 2016, and then Ronald Hundzinski, our CFO, will discuss the details of our results and guidance. 
Please note that we have posted an earnings call presentation to the IR page of the website. You'll find the link at the Events and Presentations section beneath the notice for this conference call. We encourage you to follow along with these charts during our discussion of our results. 
With that, I'll turn it over to James.

headline: BorgWarner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ken, and welcome to everybody. Thanks for joining the call today. Ron and I will spend a little bit of time here with you going through Q1 of 2016, and obviously, we'll get in and share with you some of our thoughts around the outlook for the r
componenttext:
Thank you, Ken, and welcome to everybody. Thanks for joining the call today. Ron and I will spend a little bit of time here with you going through Q1 of 2016, and obviously, we'll get in and share with you some of our thoughts around the outlook for the rest of the year. 
So you can see on Slide 2, let's start there and let me give you some of our perspective on some of the bigger picture issues, a little bit around the macro environment and then the industry in general. 
I think the headline for us as we look at the macro and the industry, this -- as we all know, there's a lot of uncertainty out there in the world, whether that's Federal Reserve issues, China monetary policy, oil, Middle East, the list is pretty extensive, and we do see a general tone of uncertainty in the general macro environment. 
That said, our view is auto is relatively stable, and I'll get into more color on that. So we see an unstable macro, but auto is in pretty good shape actually. 
If I take that down a little further and talk more specifically about our view on the market, I'll start with the light vehicle view. And we will continue to remain pretty closely aligned with IHS, as we've done through out the year, actually. So that points out projection for 2016, light vehicle growth in Europe of about 2%, North America around 4%, China, somewhere around 5% to 6%. So we continue to share a similar set of views to those of IHS. 
If I switch over to commercial vehicle, which is obviously a key market for BorgWarner, we still see that very challenged. We're not seeing a lot of uplift in news, frankly, speaking on the environment around commercial vehicle. 
On a macro global level growth, these really very little, if any. And one of the evolution, I would say, in the commercial vehicle space is we do see some of the new programs that were targeted for the out years coming into a little bit of question and review, and so we're paying a lot of attention to that. 
As we look out into 2016 from a higher level perspective, on the last call, I wanted to alert you to the areas of watch that we are paying attention to as we continue to move forward in the year. And we -- I'd like to refresh what we're watching and paying a lot of attention to. 
Commercial vehicle, I already alluded to. The secondary we're watching and paying a lot of attention to is China. And particularly, what we mean by China is I think we've all benefited from some good tailwinds around the incentives that were put in place at the end of 2015 and we're paying attention to how that evolves, particularly into the second half of the year. So what that means is are we seeing any pull forward in the first half of the year or do we see continued strength of the incentives, and I would say there's some questions there. 
Specifically, from a BorgWarner point of view, we're paying attention to, I would say, China and Europe relative to our biggest German-based customer and how that might play out to -- as the year unfolds. 
And then I think like all of us, we're going to pay a lot of attention to inventory builds and inventory building schedules in North America. So those are just some of the areas. 
With that said, things have gone well for us so far. And we're optimistic and positive about our guidance for the year, but there are some watch points and I think it's prudent of us to at least share with you why those watch points are from our viewpoint. 
Still on the same slide, let me reference some of the areas that may be of interest for you around the regulatory and technology trend area. 
We continue to see a strong drive for fuel economy and emissions regulations that are pulling our powertrain technology programs. I would articulate to the group here on the call the intensity we see around product development activity, innovation activity, is at least at the same level and potentially probably a little higher than it was several months ago around technology for fuel economy and emissions. 
So I just wanted to point that out. We're not seeing any slowdown. If anything, we've seen a little bit more work around meeting fuel economy and emissions standards to powertrain technology. 
We've engaged in some meaningful dialogue in the last quarter with -- directly with the EPA. And our view of the world is that we are not anticipating meaningful change to the 2025 CAFE standards. That's not to say that maybe some minor adjustments, and clearly, the process has to play out with further discussions. But our view at this stage is we are not seeing meaningful change. 
Just like other supplies in the space and the OEMs that you talked to, the transition to electrification of the powertrain continues to evolve and I would say accelerate. We know this a couple of years ago and we've seen that trend playing out, and we continue to see that intensify. 
Clearly, for BorgWarner, we're right in the middle of that electrification evolution. And whether that's 12 volt, 48 volt, hybrid CVs, we see a lot of activity around very -- many different architectures. And I would say to the group and not just for the long term, 7 or 8 years out, but we're seeing meaningful evolution in that space in the next 2 to 3 years. 
So more to come on that in my later comments. 
I also wanted just to anecdotally mention as this electrification trend continues, I know one of the hot buttons for the company, how does that play out for you from electric vehicles. We talked last -- on the last call that we were very proud of our EV transmission program with that will run up somewhere around 15,000 [ph] units in 2016. 
I can tell you, we've been awarded 2 additional electric vehicle programs from the company. I'm not in a position to announce the details today. We need to work with our customers to get that, but those announcements will be coming out in the next few months, and we view them as significant in how we will play in that space. 
Finally around the regulatory or technology area, let me make a couple of comment around diesel. I know that's on people's minds. I would say just similar story to what I share with you in February. We're not really seeing any meaningful mix shifts at this point. We do know and we believe that the diesel gas mix will slowly evolve and shift a little more to gas over the next couple of years. 
I think that's consistent with others viewing the space. And we see that as somewhat neutral event for BorgWarner as that technology continues to get adopted to the gasoline products at a similar level to diesel. 
Let me shift from the macro and the industry perspective and give you a little bit of a snapshot -- from our BorgWarner viewpoint. 
First of all, let me start with Q1, and obviously, Ron will give you a lot more color and details in his commentary. 
But I would tell you from my seat, I was very pleased with our Q1. I think we delivered some good growth, a little bit above expectation, which was good to see. And as you'll see in the details, very strong operating performance across the segment. 
So I went into the quarter feeling good, I come out of the quarter feeling very good. It was a good solid quarter for us. 
Versus our expectations, the revenue, I would say,, on a regional basis, China was -- China played out about as we'd expected overall. Europe, a little lower than what we'd expected. And in fact, I can give a little bit of commentary on that later. And North America and Korea, a little better than we've expected. 
But no meaningful big shifts. It was just a little bit of new ones in. And overall, that led to a good quarter. That quarter totaled up to $2.3 billion in sales, which when we exclude FX and Remy, that's about 4.5% growth. EPS of $0.80, which includes the noncomparables. It does, of course, include Remy. 
And our operating margin of 12.2% again for comparable thoughts, when we exclude Remy on the core business for BorgWarner was 13.2%. Strong performance. 
In fact, if I break that down a little further by segment, Engine came in at $1.4 billion, which is -- which grew at 1% as reported or 4.5% when you exclude currency. 
Our primary drivers of the growth, a good growth in Engine with turbo and VCT, variable cam timing on the engine timing side of our business. 
Our Drivetrain sales, $879 million, that's up an impressive 44%, but obviously, we get the benefit of Remy. When exclude Remy and currency, we grew at 5% in the Drivetrain segment. That was primarily driven by very good oil drive sales in North America and also in Europe. So again, good quarter. 
As we look out to 2016, you'll see that we did tweak our guidance just a little for the full year, but generally, it's pretty much unchanged, and I'll let Ron give the necessary detail around that. 
I did want to comment on the broader restructuring because you see that in some of our walks as it comes up. I want to say this. I think the transaction we did strategically we feel very positive about still. It was -- we're very comfortable with technology, we're comfortable with the customer reaction. We're customer -- we're pleased with the growth. 
The restructuring element, obviously, is taking longer than that we'd anticipated, and that's a little frustrating from a BorgWarner viewpoint. 
And let me just let me give you a high-level summary of why that is so you have a sense. What it really is is it centers around our European facilities. The Asia, South America and North America are doing great them actually. The European piece, we're in the process of having to making a lot of product moves. We're closing the plant, we're opening up on, we are building a plant up. And those multiple moves of products as part of the restructuring with our customers is taking a longer than we'd anticipated, but we're going to come through it and get back on track with Wahler. 
So just a guidance. Those reflect a less tailwind than expected for Wahler. But as you can see, we didn't change the total company margin or EPS guidance. 
I also want to share my view a little bit as we look to the second half of the year and maybe some -- I think what I would say to you is we have opportunities and we have risks. I would say the risks a little outweigh the opportunities as we see the world at this point. And let me maybe sure what I see those as. 
I mentioned earlier the China, second half of the year, we do have a little bit of angst that some of that incentive benefits that we get in has been potentially pulled into the first half. 
And as you know, our backup for the year is very heavily weighted to a lot of launches, particularly in Q3 and some of those are very significant, and we see a little bit of risk there. 
And commercial vehicle is kind of a little bit hard to read. It's hard to imagine and getting much worse than what it is, but we do pay attention to that. 
And I think the last comment I would make relative to the risk to the second half is our largest German-based customer and it's their additional risk their in China and Europe from a market share pressure point of view. 
So we've reflected that into our guidance. We believe that's the right thing to do, that's the prudent thing to do. But I do want to be very clear. I'm very comfortable and I'm very confident about our reiterating our ability to achieve our full year guidance. We're off to a good start and we'll deliver in our full year guidance. 
And that guidance, of course, is a good mid-single-digit growth and strong operating performance. 
Let me just share a couple of highlights around growth that you can see on the screen. First of all, the Remy deal, I would say at a high level, the integration is actually going well for us. And I say to you financially and operationally, it's performing about as expected, which is pretty good. 
So reaction from our customers around the technology is very positive. We have multiple customers already engaged in discussion around not just the call Remy business, starters, started systems, but a lot of activity, a lot of discussion, a lot of quoting activity around the combination products. And I would point you to the largest part of that is our activity about a combination of the former Remy motor, the BorgWarner clutching systems for hybrid vehicles. Some of you on the call may know that it's at P2 [ph] hybrid architecture. We feel very positive about where we stand on that position and more to come on that. 
Away from the Remy integration, I would tell you the coats in our booking activity remains strong and solid, very much in line with our growth expectations. So we feel good about our win rates. We feel good about the actual overall coating activity and all of that building up nicely for our future growth. 
And as I said earlier, the intensity around electrification continues and BorgWarner is right in the middle of that. 
So if I wrap all of that up and summarize before I turn it of to Ron, we're off to a good start to the year. Really good solid Q1. The business is running well. We continue to be heavily focused on driving our growth through adoption of technology. And we're upbeat and confident about our delivery and full year guidance. 
So with that, let me turn the call over to Ron who can provide more color in detail around the financials.

headline: BorgWarner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, James, and good day, everyone. So before I review the financial details, I'd like to provide you some of the financial highlights as I see them for the quarter. As James said, we have experienced very expected sales growth for the quarter.
componenttext:
Thank you, James, and good day, everyone. 
So before I review the financial details, I'd like to provide you some of the financial highlights as I see them for the quarter. 
As James said, we have experienced very expected sales growth for the quarter. We also expanded our operating margins on a comparable basis and we pull through that additional sales. 
But more importantly, for me, on the cash side, we saw a return to a number of capital spending. 
So now, as Ken mentioned, I will be referring to supplemental financial slide deck as we posted on the IR website. So I do encourage you to follow along. 
So let's start on Slide 3. On a reported basis, which includes the change in sales due to market growth, price, net new business, FX and Remy, that's a mouthful, by the way, sales were up 14.3%. However, to get a clearer picture how the core business performed, we have to exclude the impact of FX and Remy. So when you exclude those items, sales were up 4.5%, which was above our high end of our guidance range. 
Gross profit as a percentage of sales was 20.5% in the quarter. 
On a comparable basis or excluding Remy, gross margin was 20.9%, which is down 70 basis points from last year caused by the plant startups and borrow restructuring inefficiencies, as James was talking about earlier. 
SG&A as a percentage of sales was 8.3%, but on a comparable basis, SG&A was 7.8% of sales or 70 basis points improvement from a year ago. 
The company did a good job executing cost controls to offset the gross margin decline. 
R&D spending, which has included SG&A, was flat from a year ago at 3.8% of sales. However, if you do exclude Remy, engineering was at 4.2% or actually a 30% [ph] increase in absolute spend. 
Now, let's look at the year-over-year comparison for operating income, which can be found on Slide 4. 
Starting on the right, first quarter 2016 operating income adjusted for noncomparable items, but including Remy, was $276 million or 12.2% of sales. 
Excluding Remy's $11 million of net contribution to operating income, operating income was $266 million or 13.2% [ph] of sales, and that's up 10 basis points from a year ago. 
Excluding noncomparable items, Remy and FX, operating income was up $14 million on $90 [ph] million in higher sales, and that gives us an incremental margin of 15% in the quarter. 
Now I'd like to pause for a second and point out that there is a reconciliation of reported operating income or GAAP basis to operating income adjusted for noncomparable items, plus Remy, that can be found on Slide 15. This is very important, so you understand GAAP reported differences here. 
Now I can move on. As we look further down the income statement, equity and [indiscernible] earnings was about $9 million in the quarter, which is up slightly from last year. 
Interest expense and finance charges were $21 million in the quarter, up from $10 million a year ago, and this is -- increases primarily due to the $1 billion and EUR 500 million fixed-rate senior notes issued in the first and third quarters of 2015, respectively. 
Provision for income taxes in the quarter on a reported basis was $80 million. However, this included a $1 million tax benefit associated with our noncomparable charges, plus an additional $1 million favorable tax adjustment. 
You can read about each of these adjustments in our 10-Q, which will be filed later today. 
So if we exclude those items, the provision for income taxes was $82 million for an effective tax rate of 31%, and I should note, this is up from our guidance of 30%. 
Net earnings attributable to noncontrolling interest were about $9 million in line with the first quarter of 2015. 
Let's take a look at our diluted earnings per share on Slide 5. Net earnings, excluding noncomparable items, but including Remy, was $0.80 per diluted share. 
For comparison -- comparisons with prior periods, net earnings, excluding noncomparable items and Remy was $0.77 per diluted share. 
Now let's take a closer look at our operating segments in the quarter, beginning on Slide 6 of the deck. 
Reported income for the -- I'm sorry, reported Engine segment net sales were just under $1.4 billion in the quarter. 
Sales growth for the Engine segment, excluding currency, was 4.5% compared with the same period a year ago, primarily due to higher turbocharger and variable cam timing systems. 
Turning to Slide 7. Adjusted EBIT was $233 million for the Engine segment or 16.7% of sales. 
Excluding currency, the Engine segment adjusted EBIT was up $10 million on $63 million higher sales for an incremental margin of 15%. 
Turning to Slide 8. And starting from the right, Drivetrain segment net sales were $879 million for the quarter. 
Excluding Remy and FX, sales growth for the Drivetrain segment was 4.8% compared to the same period a year ago, primarily due to higher all-wheel-drive sales. 
Now on Slide 9. Adjusted EBIT was $84 million for Drivetrain segment or 9.5% of sales reported, but if exclude Remy, adjusted EBIT was 11.7% of sales, which is up 10 basis points from the prior year. 
Excluding Remy and FX, the Drivetrain segment's adjusted EBIT was up $5 million on $30 million of higher sales for an incremental margin of 15%. 
Now let's take a look at our balance sheet and cash flow. We generated $35 million of net cash from operating activities in the first quarter, which is typically our lowest quarter for cash flow. 
Our investment and working capital ramps up for the first quarter to match higher levels of business activity compared with the end of the year. 
Capital spending was $104 million in the first quarter, down from $140 million a year ago. 
Capital spending was above the trend in 2015, but we are returning to normal spending levels of 5% to 6% of sales this year. 
Free cash flow, which we defined as net cash from operating activities, less capital spending, was an outflow of $69 million in the first quarter. That's a $38 million improvement from a year ago. Again, this is a typical seasonal occurrence. 
We still expect to generate between $400 million and $475 million of free cash flow in 2016. 
At the midpoint, that's up 50% from 2015. $200 million to $300 million of this free cash flow will be used to repurchase shares in 2016. 
Looking at the balance sheet itself. Balance sheet debt increased by $48 million and cash decreased by $185 million in the first quarter compared with the end of 2015. 
The $233 million increase in net debt was primarily due to investments in working capital and share repurchases. 
We spent $80 million repurchasing 2.1 million shares in the first quarter and have scheduled for executing an expected $200 million to $300 million of share repurchases this year. 
Our net debt to net capital ratio was 37% at the end of the first quarter, that's up from 35.2% at the end of 2015. 
The net debt-to-EBITDA at the end of the year on a trailing 12-month basis was 1.5x. 
Now I'd like to discuss our 2016 guidance, which is slightly modified from our initial announcement. 
Returning to the slide deck, let's start with our sales growth guidance for the full year on Slide 10. 
Note that the baseline of 2015 net sales, excluding Remy, which was just under $7.9 billion. All in, we expect growth between 12.7% and 17.5%, which is down slightly from 13.2% to 18.3% [ph]. This change is primarily due to lower growth expectations from Remy's commercial vehicle business. We've seen the same effect in Remy and commercial vehicle we've seen in our core business. 
Currency is unchanged and net new business, pricing and market-related growth is also unchanged at 2.5% to 5.5%. 
Looking at our operating income guidance on Slide 11. From an operating performance perspective, we are expecting 16% [ph] to 18% [ph] incremental margins on our core business sales growth, which is slightly down from our previous guide of 18% to 20%. The change is due to slower progress of the Wahler restructuring, as James mentioned earlier in his remarks. Our previous guide included an $8 million tailwind from Wahler restructuring this year, which is -- has been reduced to $3 million. 
On a comparable basis, we still expect our operating income margin to be 13% [ph] or greater. And including Remy, our operating income margin still expected to be around to 12% range. 
Now on Slide 12. We have our EPS guidance. We still expect earnings of $3.11 to $3.32 [ph] per share on consolidated basis, which includes about $0.12 per share from Remy. 
Excluding Remy, we now expect earnings to be $2.99 [ph] to $3.19 per share. 
Now let's review our second quarter guidance issued this morning, starting with the sales growth on Slide 13. 
All in, we expect to grow between 10.6% and 16% in the quarter, including about 12 percentage points due to Remy. 
Excluding Remy, our growth in the quarter is expected to be between minus 1.5% to positive 3.8%, but this includes the negative impact of currency. 
Currency is expected to lower sales by 290 basis points at the low end and 100 basis points on the high end. So if it exclude Remy in currency, the impact of net new business, pricing and market-related growth will drive growth between 1.5% to 4.5% in Q2. 
Turning to Slide 14. We expect earnings of $0.78 to $0.83 per share on a consolidated basis in the second quarter, which includes about $0.03 per share from Remy. 
Excluding Remy, we expect earnings to be $0.75 to $0.80 per share. 
I'd like to make a few concluding remarks. We had a good first quarter. Sales growth exceeded our expectations and we full this through to operating income. But more importantly, the first half of 2015 was a challenging year for us and we were having a difficult time setting our sales guidance because of the market index that we have in BorgWarner. And as a result, this impacted earnings expectations last year. 
However, over the last 3 quarters, we have settled this down and we've achieved our sales and earnings expectations. 
So as we look at the rest of the year, we expect to continue on this path, solid sales growth, strong operating margins and improve cash flow for the year. 
I remain confident we will deliver our 2016 guidance similar to what James expressed earlier. 
And with that, I'd like to that the call over to Ken.

componenttext: Yes, that's a good way to think about it, Rich. Yes, that -- no, that is the good way. That, and that's the kind of where it will be useful to at least let you know what some of them could be. We don't necessarily saying that will happen, but we just think it's prudent. componenttext: No, that's a great thought, Brett. Let me take a shot of that, okay? So first thing I would say, we're in the first year of the net new business. And as we're communicating, we're comfortable, confident and feeling pretty good about this year, okay? So that's where -- what we think. As we look out, I'm going to say a couple of things. Are we comfortable internally as a company with the projection we made? Yes. Do we like it? Not really. I'd rather be much higher than 4% to 6%, but we're working like crazy to get higher than 4% to 6%. And as we get through this year, we will have a better read at what that looks like. And obviously, we need a little bit more time. So our focus right now is we're comfortable with what's out there. We're going to execute and perform against it, which I think we're starting to do, which is really good. And I would say incrementally, as I look out, we will go up from single-digit growth at some point. It's not yet. That's kind of the way to think of it, Brett. We will. And I don't anticipate that it's certainly not '16 [ph] and I don't think yet it would be '17 either. I want you to know BorgWarner is not happy being a mid-single-digit growth company. We're going to go -- we're not. We're going to focus like crazy to go higher than that. But it's too early, Brett. We got to delivery and we got to execute on the mid-single-digit growth. I think the Investor Day will -- that's later this year will help provide some clarity and color on why we believe this opportunity to transition up, but it is too early at this point, Brett. We need a little more time to execute, deliver and do our work.

componenttext: Yes. I think -- yes, you're right, Brett. First, there anyone really is flawless execution of the Remy, which I'm pleased with how that's going. I'm pretty comfortable there. And I think from a resource perspective, we feel comfortable. So what I'm saying to you is we're not slowing down our efforts to look at smaller bolt-on related deals. Whether it would be this year or next year, Brett, we always know that's kind of hard to predict the accurate timing. But I wouldn't want you to think or anybody to think that we've done Remy, that's all we do and that's stopped kind of walking and talking about the deal because that's not the case. We are, we are. They would be clearly, I think, smaller than obviously Remy transaction. And they would be likely bolt-on complementary type technologies to what we have. So if that helps, Brett, that's what we're thinking.

componenttext: Yes. I can comment on that for sure. I think I mentioned earlier that we are not seeing any slowdown within the dialogue and the discussion around the need for technology to drive better fuel economy, emissions and vehicle performance. I know there's a lot of a bit of deception out there, but that's going to slow down. And so dollars can be shifted over to these other technologies. We have not seen that. Our activities is as good as it's ever been in terms of working with our OEMs. And the equation, the business equation has not changed. It's purely a value equation of how can the OEM meet their fuel economy and emissions standards at the minimal cost, frankly, so that it minimizes any impact on the end consumer. And when I look across the suite of BorgWarner products that do that, we're in a very, very good position. That's why we're delivering the small strong mid-single-digit growth we are. The adoption rates to our products remain very strong and they will do because they're very good cost-effective solutions that get the automakers where they need to in a way that they can support their end consumer.

componenttext: Couple of questions, please. In your comments, James, you talked a little bit about commercial trucks outlook and how that's impacting BorgWarner. Is commercial truck still going to be viewed by BorgWarner as being a core market or is commercial truck is something that BorgWarner might start to move away from?

headline: BorgWarner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, commercial truck is a key part of our business. I mean, clearly, it's challenged right now in terms of the market conditions. We've seen globally, no real growth in that sector, if you wish, for a while. But we're in there. BorgWarner has continued to
componenttext: No, commercial truck is a key part of our business. I mean, clearly, it's challenged right now in terms of the market conditions. We've seen globally, no real growth in that sector, if you wish, for a while. But we're in there. BorgWarner has continued to grow in that sector. Obviously, we grow at a much faster pace of the light vehicle side of the business. So now, the commercial vehicle business is still remain very core to us. We have a number of our products across the portfolio that play in commercial vehicle. Clearly, the Remy transaction we did has a strong presence in commercial vehicle, and that was attractive to us. So now we're -- we remain committed to commercial vehicle. I think what we'll always see is with 80% plus of our business has car related and a lot of that growth impacts cars as an end market, you're going to see that growth generally outweighs in light vehicle over commercial vehicle. But that doesn't step us away from our focus and commitment around commercial vehicle.

componenttext: Yes, absolutely, Richard. That's what we do today, actually. If you think of a lot of that what you could say commercial vehicle-oriented turbocharger technology, we can and we do apply to the light vehicle side of the business and vice versa, by the way. We run our turbo business, as an example. It's a very integrated business that's very -- creates a lot of synergies from a technology perspective between the commercial vehicle and the light vehicle. Another great example is we apply that transmission technology that from light vehicle, as you know, with Volkswagen and we're applying that to the trucks. So that's another very good example. Our cooling thermal, cooling technology, technology, cooling pumps, we apply those across both light and commercial vehicle. So yes, it's definitely. And as you think of the global situation, which where a lot of trucks, commercial trucks that is -- are getting smaller, think of like little delivery van technologies and you think in some markets, light -- so-called light vehicles are getting bigger, large pickup truck, vehicles and SUVs, there's a blend of technologies that comes together to can offer competitive position. I think we do that actually very well.

componenttext: John, I'll take that one. I did a couple of things. We -- obviously, we do see the EV market evolving. It's -- our macro perspective is we generally pointed to 2025 timeline of about a couple of percent of the fleet. The world fleet would be EVs. We've always said that could be a 1%, 2% higher or a little lower, but in that range, 2%, 3% on them. We're not moving at this point away from that view, John. I would say incrementally, we'd see more energy enthusiasm and intensity income around electric vehicles. I would say the bigger message we're trying to get across, John, is this overhang of with EVs, BorgWarner doesn't have anything. It's simply not true, and that's kind of what we're trying to articulate that we will serve that market. And this is a great example of hard parts in assets that were going into electric vehicles leveraging BorgWarner's technology, and it's in China, and it's been a reasonable volume, whether it's 15,000 [ph] this year. So macro, not really change on EV, John, 2%, 3% likely in the future. China, probably getting incremental, a little more aggressive that way. But the key message is BorgWarner is going to be in that space in play.

componenttext: Yes, I think, I would say this, John, as I mentioned earlier, we've not done anything with our guidance to move away from any meaningful truck mix, truck car mix are in North America. And the drivers for us, and I think you know this, John, as that truck mix goes and may stop in meaningful forward driver, overdrive transportation capability and turbocharge engines, that starts the step up the content pretty meaningful for BorgWarner. We have to watch and we do the GM truck share ratio because while our content is very strong on the forward side, it's less much less so on the GM side, so to be transparent with you.

componenttextpreview: I would say, Joe, from our viewpoint, I would say that coating activity in general across all electrification architectures is very strong and probably getting even stronger. A lot of the dialogue we will be in because this is how BorgWarner operates is m
componenttext: I would say, Joe, from our viewpoint, I would say that coating activity in general across all electrification architectures is very strong and probably getting even stronger. A lot of the dialogue we will be in because this is how BorgWarner operates is many times with the dialogue with the customer will be, they're not sure if they want a 12 volt or 48 and a 12 and a 48 volt. People like BorgWarner can help them find that conclusion. So I'm not necessarily in the view that there's been a massive uptick in pure 48 volt architecture. I think they're differently going to move up in electrification architecture, which we've talked about for a while. And I see the surprise they're going to win just James' view, other ones that can service the flexibility between 12 and 48 volt and not rely on either one. And we have a bunch of products that do that. So whether that's electric turbocharger, whether that's former Remy motor technology, just to name a couple. So yes, it's strong and we're right in the midst of it.

Good morning. My name is Melissa, and I will be your conference facilitator. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the BorgWarner 2016 First Quarter Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] 
I would now like to turn the call over to Ken Lamb, VP of Investor Relations. Mr. Lamb, you may begin your conference.

headline: BorgWarner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Melissa. Good morning, and thank all of you for joining us. We issued our earnings release this morning at around 8:00 a.m. Eastern. It's posted on our website, borgwarner.com, on our Investor Relations homepage. A replay of today's conference
componenttext:
Thank you, Melissa. Good morning, and thank all of you for joining us. We issued our earnings release this morning at around 8:00 a.m. Eastern. It's posted on our website, borgwarner.com, on our Investor Relations homepage. A replay of today's conference call will be available through May 13. The dial-in number for that replay is (800) 585-8367. You'll need the conference ID, which is 77109071, or you can listen to the replay on our website. 
With regard to our Investor Relations calendar, we will be attending the following conferences between now and our next earnings release: The Wells Fargo Industrials Conference in New York on May 10; The Barclays America's Select Conference in London on May 18; The KeyBanc Automotive, Industrial and Transportation Conference in Boston on June 1; Deutsche Bank Industrials Conference in Chicago on June 9; and The Citi Industrials Conference in Boston on June 14. 
Now back to today's earnings release. Before we begin, I need to inform you that during this call, we may make forward-looking statements, which involve risks and uncertainties as detailed in our 10-K. Our actual results may differ significantly from the matters discussed today. 
Now moving on to our results. James Verrier, President and CEO, will comment on the industry and provide a high-level overview of our result and expectations for the remainder of 2016, and then Ronald Hundzinski, our CFO, will discuss the details of our results and guidance. 
Please note that we have posted an earnings call presentation to the IR page of the website. You'll find the link at the Events and Presentations section beneath the notice for this conference call. We encourage you to follow along with these charts during our discussion of our results. 
With that, I'll turn it over to James.

headline: BorgWarner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ken, and welcome to everybody. Thanks for joining the call today. Ron and I will spend a little bit of time here with you going through Q1 of 2016, and then obviously, we'll get in and share with you some of our thoughts around the outlook for
componenttext:
Thank you, Ken, and welcome to everybody. Thanks for joining the call today. Ron and I will spend a little bit of time here with you going through Q1 of 2016, and then obviously, we'll get in and share with you some of our thoughts around the outlook for the rest of the year. 
So you can see on Slide 2, let's start there and let me give you some of our perspective on some of the bigger picture issues, a little bit around the macro environment and then the industry in general. 
I think the headline for us as we look at the macro and the industry, this -- as we all know, there's a lot of uncertainty out there in the world, whether that's Federal Reserve issues, China monetary policy, oil, Middle East. The list is pretty extensive, and we do see a general tone of uncertainty in the general macro environment. 
That said, our view is that auto is relatively stable, and I'll get into more color on that. So we see an unstable macro, but auto is in pretty good shape actually. 
If I take that down a little further and talk more specifically about our view on the market, I'll start with the light vehicle view. And we will continue to remain pretty closely aligned with IHS, as we've done through out the year actually. So that points us to a projection for 2016, light vehicle growth in Europe of about 2%, North America around 4%, China somewhere around 5% to 6%. So we continue to share a similar set of views to those of IHS. 
If I switch over to commercial vehicle, which is obviously a key market for BorgWarner, we still see that very challenged. We're not seeing a lot of uplift in news, frankly speaking, on the environments around commercial vehicle. 
On a macro global level growth, these really very little, if any. And one of the evolution I would say in the commercial vehicle space is, we do see some of the new programs that were targeted for the out years coming into a little bit of question and review, and so we're paying a lot of attention to that. 
As we look out into 2016 from a higher level perspective, on the last call, I wanted to alert you to the areas of watch that we are paying attention to as we continue to move forward in the year. And we -- I'd like to refresh what we're watching and paying a lot of attention to. 
Commercial vehicle, I already alluded to. The secondary we're watching and paying a lot of attention to is China. And particularly, what we mean by China is, I think, we've all benefited from some good tailwinds around the incentives that were put in place at the end of 2015, and we're paying attention to how that evolves, particularly into the second half of the year. So what that means is are we seeing any pull forward in the first half of the year or do we see continued strength from the incentives, and I would say there's some questions there. 
Specifically, from a BorgWarner point of view, we're paying attention to, I would say, China and Europe relative to our biggest German-based customer and how that might play out to as the year unfolds. 
And then I think, like all of us, we're going to pay a lot of attention to inventory builds and inventory building schedules in North America. So those are just some of the areas. 
With that said, things have gone well for us so far. And we're optimistic and positive about our guidance for the year, but there are some watch points, and I think it's prudent of us to at least share with you what those watch points are from our viewpoint. 
Still on the same slide, let me reference some of the areas that might be of interest for you around the regulatory and technology trend area. 
We continue to see a strong drive for fuel economy and emissions regulations that are pulling our powertrain technology programs. I would articulate to the group here on the call, the intensity we see around product development activity, innovation activity is at least at the same level and potentially probably a little higher than it was several months ago around technology for fuel economy and emissions. 
So I just wanted to point that out. We're not seeing any slowdown. If anything, we're seeing a little bit more work around meeting fuel economy and emissions standards for powertrain technology. 
We've engaged in some meaningful dialogue in the last quarter with -- directly with the EPA. And our view of the world is that we are not anticipating meaningful change to the 2025 CAFE standards. That's not to say there maybe some minor adjustments, and clearly, the process has to play out with further discussions. But our view at this stage is we are not seeing meaningful change. 
Just like other suppliers in the space and the OEMs that you talked to, the transition to electrification of the powertrain continues to evolve, and I would say accelerate. We know this at -- a couple of years ago when we've seen that trend playing out, and we continue to see that intensify. 
Clearly, for BorgWarner, we're right in the middle of that electrification evolution. And whether that's 12 volt, 48 volt, hybrid CVs, we see a lot of activity around very -- many different architectures. And I would say to the group, and not just for the long term, 7 or 8 years out, but we're seeing meaningful evolution in that space in the next 2 to 3 years. 
So more to come on that in my later comments. 
I also wanted just to anecdotally mention as this electrification trend continues. I know one of the hot buttons for the company, and how does that play out for you from electric vehicles. We talked last -- on the last call that we were very proud of our EV transmission program with Geely that will run up somewhere around about 15,000 units in 2016. 
I can tell you we've been awarded 2 additional electric vehicle programs for the company. I'm not in a position to announce the details today. We need to work with our customers to get that, but those announcements will be coming out in the next few months, and we view them as significant in how we will play in that space. 
Finally around the regulatory or technology area, let me make a couple of comment around diesel, I know that's on people's minds. I would say just similar story to what I shared with you in February. We're not really seeing any meaningful mix shifts at this point. We do know, and we believe that the diesel/gas mix will slowly evolve and shift a little more to gas over the next couple of years. 
I think that's consistent with others viewing the space. And we see that as somewhat neutral event for BorgWarner as that technology continues to get adopted to the gasoline products at a similar level to diesel. 
Let me shift from the macro and the industry perspective and give you a little bit of a snapshot of -- from a BorgWarner viewpoint. 
First of all, let me start with Q1, and obviously, Ron will give you a lot more color and details in his commentary. 
But I would tell you from my seat, I was very pleased with our Q1. I think we delivered some good growth, a little bit above expectation, which was good to see. And as you'll see in the details, very strong operating performance across the segment. 
So I went into the quarter feeling good, I come out of the quarter feeling very good. It was a good solid quarter for us. 
Versus our expectations, the revenue, I would say, upon a regional basis, China was -- China played out about as we'd expected overall. Europe, a little lower than what we'd expected. And in fact, I can give a little bit of commentary on that later. And North America and Korea, a little better than we'd expected. 
But no meaningful big shifts. It was just a little bit of new ones in. And overall, that led to a good quarter. That quarter totaled up to $2.3 billion in sales, which when we exclude FX and Remy, that's about 4.5% growth. EPS of $0.80, which includes the noncomparables. It does, of course, include Remy. 
And our operating margin of 12.2% again for comparable thoughts when we exclude Remy on the core business for BorgWarner was 13.2%. Strong performance. 
If I break that down a little further by segment, Engine came in at $1.4 billion, which is -- which grew at 1% as reported or 4.5% when you exclude currency. 
Our primary drivers of the growth or good growth in Engine were turbo and VCT, variable cam timing, on the engine timing side of our business. 
Our Drivetrain sales, $879 million, that's up an impressive 44%, but obviously, we get the benefit of Remy. When we exclude Remy and currency, we grew at 5% in the Drivetrain segment. That was primarily driven by very good all-wheel drive sales in North America and also in Europe. So again, good quarter. 
As we look out for 2016, you'll see that we did tweak our guidance just a little for the full year, but generally, it's pretty much unchanged, and I'll let Ron give the necessary detail around that. 
I did want to comment on the broader restructuring because you see that in some of our walks as it comes up. I want to say this. I think that the Wahler transaction we did, strategically, we feel very positive about still. It was -- we're very comfortable with technology, we're comfortable with the customer reaction. We're customer -- we're pleased with the growth. 
The restructuring element obviously is taking longer than that we'd anticipated, and that's a little frustrating from a BorgWarner viewpoint. 
And let me just maybe give you a high-level summary of why that is, so you have a sense. What it really is it centers around our European facilities. The Asia, South America and North America are doing great actually. The European piece, we're in the process of having to make a lot of product moves. We're closing the plant, we're opening the plant, we are building a plant up. And those multiple moves of products, as part of the restructuring, with our customers is taking a little longer than we'd anticipated, but we're going to come through it and get back on track with Wahler. 
So our adjusted guidance does reflect a little less tailwind than expected for Wahler. But as you can see, we didn't change the total company margin or EPS guidance. 
I also want to share my view a little bit on as we look to the second half of the year and maybe some -- I think what I would say to you is we have opportunities and we have risks. I would say the risks little outweigh the opportunities as we see the world at this point. And let me maybe share what I see those as. 
I mentioned earlier the China, second half of the year, we do have a little bit of angst that some of that incentive benefits that we're getting has been potentially pulled into the first half. 
And as you know, our back half for the year is very heavily weighted to a lot of launches, particularly in Q3, and some of those are very significant, and we see a little bit of risk there. 
And commercial vehicle is kind of a little bit hard to read. It's hard to imagine it getting much worse than what it is, but we do pay attention to that. 
And I think the last comment I would make relative to the risk to the second half is our largest German-based customer and it's their additional risk their in China and Europe from a market share pressure point of view. 
So we've reflected that into our guidance. We believe that's the right thing to do, that's the prudent thing to do. But I do want to be very clear. I'm very comfortable, and I'm very confident about reiterating our ability to achieve our full year guidance. We're off to a good start, and we'll deliver on our full year guidance. 
And that guidance, of course, is a good mid-single-digit growth and strong operating performance. 
Let me just share a couple of highlights around growth that you can see on the screen. First of all, the Remy deal, I would say at a high level, the integration is actually going well for us. And I'd say to you, financially and operationally, it's performing about as expected, which is pretty good. 
So reaction from our customers around the technology is very positive. We have multiple customers already engaged in discussion around not just the core Remy business, starters, alternators, belt-alternator, starter systems, but a lot of activity, a lot of discussion, a lot of quoting activity around the combination products. And I would point you to the largest part of that is our activity about the combination of the former Remy motor, the BorgWarner clutching systems for hybrid vehicles. Some of you on the call may know that it's a P2 hybrid architecture. We feel very positive about where we stand on that position and more to come on that. 
Away from the Remy integration, I will tell you the coats, and our booking activity remains strong and solid, very much in line with our growth expectations. So we feel good about our win rates. We feel good about the actual overall coating activity and all of that building up nicely for our future growth. 
And as I said earlier, the intensity around electrification continues and BorgWarner is right in the middle of that. 
So if I wrap all of that up and summarize before I turn it off to Ron, we're off to a good start to the year. Really good solid Q1. The business is running well. We continue to be heavily focused on driving our growth through adoption of technology. And we're upbeat and confident about our delivery on our full year guidance. 
So with that, let me turn the call over to Ron who can provide more color and detail around the financials.

headline: BorgWarner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, James, and good day, everyone. So before I review the financial details, I'd like to provide you some of the financial highlights as I see them for the quarter. As James said, we have experienced [indiscernible] expected sales growth for th
componenttext:
Thank you, James, and good day, everyone. 
So before I review the financial details, I'd like to provide you some of the financial highlights as I see them for the quarter. 
As James said, we have experienced [indiscernible] expected sales growth for the quarter. We also expanded our operating margins on a comparable basis, and we flow-through that additional sales. 
But more importantly for me, on the cash side, we saw a return to normal CapEx spending. 
So now, as Ken mentioned, I will be referring to the supplemental financial slide deck as we posted on the IR website. So I do encourage you to follow along. 
So let's start on Slide 3. On a reported basis, which includes the change in sales due to market growth, price, net new business, FX and Remy, that's a mouthful by the way, sales were up 14.3%. However, to get a clearer picture of how the core business performed, we have to exclude the impact of FX and Remy. So when you exclude those items, sales were up 4.5%, which was above our high end of our guidance range. 
Gross profit as a percentage of sales was 20.5% in the quarter. 
On a comparable basis or excluding Remy, gross margin was 20.9%, which is down 70 basis points from last year, caused by plant start-ups and borrow restructuring inefficiencies, as James was talking about earlier. 
SG&A as a percentage of sales was 8.3%, but on a comparable basis, SG&A was 7.8% of sales or 70 basis points improvement from a year ago. 
The company did a good job executing cost controls to offset the gross margin decline. 
R&D spending, which has included SG&A, was flat from a year ago at 3.8% of sales. However, if you do exclude Remy, engineering was at 4.2% or actually a 30% increase in absolute spend. 
Now let's look at the year-over-year comparison for operating income, which can be found on Slide 4. 
Starting on the right, first quarter 2016 operating income, adjusted for noncomparable items, but including Remy, was $276 million or 12.2% of sales. 
Excluding Remy's $11 million of net contribution to operating income, operating income was $266 million or 13.2% of sales, and that's up 10 basis points from a year ago. 
Excluding noncomparable items, Remy and FX, operating income was up $14 million on $90 million in higher sales, and that gives us an incremental margin of 15% in the quarter. 
Now I'd like to pause for a second and point out that there is a reconciliation of reported operating income or GAAP basis to operating income adjusted for noncomparable items, plus Remy, and can be found on Slide 15. This is very important. So you understand as a GAAP reported differences here. 
Now I can move on. As we look further down the income statement, equity in the [indiscernible] earnings was about $9 million in the quarter, which is up slightly from last year. 
Interest expense and finance charges were $21 million in the quarter, up from $10 million a year ago, and this is -- increase is primarily due to the $1 billion and EUR 500 million fixed-rate senior notes issued in the first and third quarters of 2015, respectively. 
Provision for income taxes in the quarter on a reported basis was $80 million. However, this included a $1 million tax benefit associated with their noncomparable charges plus an additional $1 million favorable tax adjustment. 
You can read about each of these adjustments in our 10-Q, which will be filed later today. 
So if we exclude those items, the provision for income taxes was $82 million for an effective tax rate of 31%, and I should note, this is up from our guidance of 30%. 
Net earnings attributable to noncontrolling interest were about $9 million in line with the first quarter of 2015. 
Let's take a look at our diluted earnings per share on Slide 5. Net earnings, excluding noncomparable items, but including Remy, was $0.80 per diluted share. 
For comparison -- comparisons with prior periods, net earnings, excluding noncomparable items and Remy, was $0.77 per diluted share. 
Now let's take a closer look at our operating segments in the quarter, beginning on Slide 6 of the deck. 
Reported income for the -- I'm sorry, reported Engine segment net sales were just under $1.4 billion in the quarter. 
Sales growth for the Engine segment, excluding currency, was 4.5% compared with the same period a year ago, primarily due to higher turbocharger and variable cam timing systems. 
Turning to Slide 7. Adjusted EBIT was $233 million for the Engine segment or 16.7% of sales. 
Excluding currency, the Engine segment's adjusted EBIT was up $10 million on $63 million of higher sales for an incremental margin of 15%. 
Turning to Slide 8. And starting from the right, Drivetrain segment net sales were $879 million for the quarter. 
Excluding Remy and FX, sales growth for the Drivetrain segment was 4.8% compared to the same period a year ago, primarily due to higher all-wheel drive sales. 
Now on Slide 9. Adjusted EBIT was $84 million for Drivetrain segment or 9.5% of sales reported, but it exclude Remy, adjusted EBIT was 11.7% of sales, which is up 10 basis points from the prior year. 
Excluding Remy and FX, the Drivetrain segment's adjusted EBIT was up $5 million on $30 million of higher sales for an incremental margin of 15%. 
Now let's take a look at our balance sheet and cash flow. We generated $35 million of net cash from operating activities in the first quarter, which is typically our lowest quarter for cash flow. 
Our investment and working capital ramps up for the first quarter to match higher levels of business activity compared with the end of the year. 
Capital spending was $104 million in the first quarter, down from $140 million a year ago. 
Capital spending was above the trend in 2015, but we are returning to normal spending levels of 5% to 6% of sales this year. 
Free cash flow, which we defined as net cash from operating activities, less capital spending, was an outflow of $69 million in the first quarter. That's a $38 million improvement from a year ago. Again, this is a typical seasonal occurrence. 
We still expect to generate between $400 million and $475 million of free cash flow in 2016. 
At the midpoint, that's up 50% from 2015. $200 million to $300 million of this free cash flow will be used to repurchase shares in 2016. 
Looking at the balance sheet itself. Balance sheet debt increased by $48 million and cash decreased by $185 million in the first quarter compared with the end of 2015. 
The $233 million increase in net debt was primarily due to investments in working capital and share repurchases. 
We spent $80 million repurchasing 2.1 million shares in the first quarter and have scheduled for executing an expected $200 million to $300 million of share repurchases this year. 
Our net debt to net capital ratio was 37% at the end of the first quarter, that's up from 35.2% at the end of 2015. 
The net debt to EBITDA at the end of the year on a trailing 12-month basis was 1.5x. 
Now I'd like to discuss our 2016 guidance, which is slightly modified from our initial announcement. 
Returning to the slide deck. Let's start with our sales growth guidance for the full year on Slide 10. 
Note that the baseline of 2015 net sales, excluding Remy, which was just under $7.9 billion. All in, we expect growth between 12.7% and 17.5%, which is down slightly from 13.2% to 18.3%. This change is primarily due to lower growth expectations from Remy's commercial vehicle business. We're seeing the same effect in Remy and commercial vehicle we're seeing in our core business. 
Currency is unchanged and net new business, pricing and market-related growth is also unchanged at 2.5% to 5.5%. 
Looking at our operating income guidance on Slide 11. From an operating performance perspective, we are expecting 16% to 18% incremental margins on our core business sales growth, which is slightly down from our previous guide of 18% to 20%. The change is due to slower progress of the Wahler restructuring, as James mentioned earlier in his remarks. Our previous guide included an $8 million tailwind from Wahler restructuring this year, which is -- has been reduced to $3 million. 
On a comparable basis, we still expect our operating income margin to be 13% or greater. And including Remy, our operating income margin is still expected to be around the 12% range. 
Now on Slide 12. We have our EPS guidance. We still expect earnings of $3.11 to $3.32 per share on a consolidated basis, which includes about $0.12 per share from Remy. 
Excluding Remy, we now expect earnings to be $2.99 to $3.19 per share. 
Now let's review our second quarter guidance issued this morning, starting with the sales growth on Slide 13. 
All in, we expect to grow between 10.6% and 16% in the quarter, including about 12 percentage points due to Remy. 
Excluding Remy, our growth in the quarter is expected to be between minus 1.5% to positive 3.8%, but this includes the negative impact of currency. 
Currency is expected to lower sales by 290 basis points at the low end and 100 basis points on the high end. So if we exclude Remy in currency, the impact of net new business, pricing and market-related growth will drive growth between 1.5% to 4.5% in Q2. 
Now turning to Slide 14. We expect earnings of $0.78 to $0.83 per share on a consolidated basis in the second quarter, which includes about $0.03 per share from Remy. 
Excluding Remy, we expect earnings to be $0.75 to $0.80 per share. 
I'd like to make a few concluding remarks. We had a good first quarter. Sales growth exceeded our expectations, and we flow this through to our operating income. But more importantly, the first half of 2015 was a challenging year for us, and we were having a difficult time setting their sales guidance because of the market indexing that we have in BorgWarner. And as a result, this impacted earnings expectations last year. 
However, over the last 3 quarters, we have settled this down, and we've achieved our sales and earnings expectations. 
So as we look at the rest of the year, we expect to continue on this path, solid sales growth, strong operating margins and improve cash flow for the year. 
I remain confident that we will deliver our 2016 guidance similar to what James expressed earlier. 
And with that, I'd like to turn over the call back to Ken.

componenttext: Yes, that's a good way to think about it, Rich. Yes, that -- no, that is the good way and that -- and that's kind of why I thought it would be useful to at least let you know what some of them could be. We are not necessarily saying that will happen, but we just thought it was prudent. And it does get back a little bit to the China story a little. We've seen some acceleration in the first half on these incentives that might weigh a little bit on the back-end Clearly, we have the Volkswagen business with China, particularly, and Europe from a market share risk point of view. And just on that one, Rich, as an example, we saw some of that way on us in the first quarter with China in -- Volkswagen in China. You can see the numbers, right? They were down in production pretty significantly in the first quarter. That still 20%-plus of our business. So -- and then the last one, Rich, is we've got some pretty big launches, which we've talked about on the prior calls with -- whether that's Pentastar, whether that's Super Duty, the Duramax. And so these are all, I would say, Rich, these are all kind of pretty small new ones and things. componenttext: I wanted to kind of take a step back and just ask a longer-term conceptual question. You've obviously provided the backlog guidance as 4% to 6% through 2018. My question is this. If you kind of look that backlog number, that growth number, how do we -- how should we think about kind of upside versus downside? Upside opportunity versus downside risk? headline: BorgWarner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. That's a great thought, Brett. Let me take a shot at it, okay? So first thing I would say, we're in the first year of the net new business. And as we're communicating, we're comfortable, confident and feeling pretty good about this year, okay? So that
componenttext: No. That's a great thought, Brett. Let me take a shot at it, okay? So first thing I would say, we're in the first year of the net new business. And as we're communicating, we're comfortable, confident and feeling pretty good about this year, okay? So that's where -- what we think. As we look out, I'm going to say a couple of things. Are we comfortable internally as a company with the projection we made? Yes. Do we like it? Not really. I'd rather be much higher than 4% to 6%, and we're working like crazy to get higher than 4% to 6%. And as we get through this year, we will have a better read of what that looks like. And obviously, we need a little bit more time. So our focus right now is we're comfortable with what's out there. We're going to execute and perform against it, which I think we're starting to do, which is really good. And I would say incrementally, as I look out, we will go up from mid-single-digit growth at some point, if's not yet. That's kind of the way to think of it, Brett. We will. And I don't anticipate that it's certainly not '16, and I don't think it would be '17 either. I want you to know BorgWarner is not happy being a mid-single-digit growth company. We're going to go -- we're not. We're going to focus like crazy to go higher than that. But it's too early, Brett. We got to delivery and we got to execute on the mid-single-digit growth. I think the Investor Day will -- that's later this year will help provide some clarity and color on why we believe this opportunity to transition up, but it is too early at this point, Brett. We need a little more time to execute, deliver and do our work.

headline: BorgWarner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Fair enough. And then switching gears. Thank you, James. As we think about M&A activity, obviously, you're digesting Remy and fairly large acquisition for you. We-- as you kind of think about M&A activity, should we think about it as kind of subsidi
componenttext: Okay. Fair enough. And then switching gears. Thank you, James. As we think about M&A activity, obviously, you're digesting Remy and fairly large acquisition for you. We-- as you kind of think about M&A activity, should we think about it as kind of subsiding for another for the next quarter or 2, 3, 4 quarters until you digest what you've kind of bitten off so far? Or can we expect maybe some additional bolt-ons through the remainder of this year or in the next year?

headline: BorgWarner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think -- yes, you're right, Brett. First, the priority one really is flawless execution on the Remy deal, which I'm pleased with how that's going. From a financial perspective, we feel comfortable that if another deal came along, we could do it and
componenttext: Yes. I think -- yes, you're right, Brett. First, the priority one really is flawless execution on the Remy deal, which I'm pleased with how that's going. From a financial perspective, we feel comfortable that if another deal came along, we could do it and we would do it. So I don't feel too inhibited from a smaller size bolt-on acquisition. I'm pretty comfortable there. And I think from a resource perspective, we feel comfortable. So what I'm saying to you is we're not slowing down our efforts to look at smaller bolt-on related deals. Whether it would be this year or next year, Brett, we always know that's kind of hard to predict the accurate timing. But I wouldn't want you to think or anybody to think that we've done Remy, that's all we do, and then we'll stop kind of looking and working and talking about deals because that's not the case. We are, we are. They would be clearly, I think, smaller than obviously the Remy transaction. And they would be likely bolt-on complementary-type technologies to what we have. So if that helps you, Brett, that's what we're thinking.

componenttext: I would articulate it this way. The -- think of it in 2 ways. It's a little early to know how that's going to translate into revenue. We need a little more time. But I would articulate the conversations have been open and productive and good thus far. As I allude -- mentioned in my opening commentary, the energy, intensity, excitement around the combination of products in future technology packages, combining former Remy and BorgWarner, has probably exceeded our expectations from when we did the deal. As we've always said, that's a longer-term revenue play. Those are 3-, 5-year-type offerings. But I would say to you, those have been extremely positive.

Any thoughts on how the consumer prioritizes different content and is actually able to afford all this increase in cost?

headline: BorgWarner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I can comment on that for sure. I think I mentioned earlier that we are not seeing any slowdown in the dialogue and the discussion around the need for technology to drive better fuel economy, emissions and vehicle performance. I know there's a lot of
componenttext: Yes. I can comment on that for sure. I think I mentioned earlier that we are not seeing any slowdown in the dialogue and the discussion around the need for technology to drive better fuel economy, emissions and vehicle performance. I know there's a lot of a bit of perception out there that, that's going to slow down. And so dollars can be shifted over to these other technologies. We have not seen that. Our activities as good as it's ever been in terms of working with our OEMs. And the equation -- the business equation has not changed. It's purely a value equation of how can the OEM meet their fuel economy and emissions standards at the minimal cost, frankly, so it minimizes any impact on the end consumer. And when I look across the suite of BorgWarner products that do that, we're in a very, very good position. That's why we're delivering the strong mid-single-digit growth we are. The adoption rates for our products remain very strong and they will do because they're very good cost-effective solutions to get the automakers where they need to in a way that they can support their end consumer.

componenttext: Couple of questions, please. In your comments, James, you talked a little bit about commercial truck outlook, and how that impacting BorgWarner? Is commercial truck still going to be viewed by BorgWarner as being a core market? Or is commercial truck something that BorgWarner might start to move away from?

headline: BorgWarner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Commercial truck, Richard, is a key part of our business. I mean, clearly, it's challenged right now in terms of the market conditions. We've seen globally, no real growth in that sector, if you wish for a while, but we're in there. BorgWarner has con
componenttext: No. Commercial truck, Richard, is a key part of our business. I mean, clearly, it's challenged right now in terms of the market conditions. We've seen globally, no real growth in that sector, if you wish for a while, but we're in there. BorgWarner has continued to grow in that sector. Obviously, we grow at a much faster pace on the light vehicle side of the business. So now the commercial vehicle businesses still remains very core to us. We have a number of our products across the portfolio that play in commercial vehicle. Clearly, the Remy transaction we did has a strong presence in commercial vehicle, and that was attractive to us. So now we're -- we remain committed to commercial vehicle. I think what we'll always see is with 80%-plus of our business is pass car related and a lot of growth impacts car as an end market, you're going to see that growth generally outweighs in light vehicle over commercial vehicle. But that doesn't step us away from our focus and commitment around commercial vehicle.

headline: BorgWarner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: With the emissions legislation, the cleaner legislation around the world getting more stringent, not only on passenger cars, but also on commercial as well as stationary applications or Marine applications, whatever the case may be, are there any types of fuel efficiency or things that are attractive to BorgWarner on the commercial side that can be adopted from passenger or some new technologies that might fit in with BorgWarner strategy on commercial?

headline: BorgWarner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely, Richard. That's what we do today, actually. If you think of a lot of that what you could say commercial vehicle-oriented turbocharger technology, we can and we do apply to the light vehicle side of the business and vice versa, by the way.
componenttext: Yes, absolutely, Richard. That's what we do today, actually. If you think of a lot of that what you could say commercial vehicle-oriented turbocharger technology, we can and we do apply to the light vehicle side of the business and vice versa, by the way. We run our turbo business, as an example, as a very integrated business that's very -- creates a lot of synergies from a technology perspective between the commercial vehicle and the light vehicle. Another great example is we apply that dual-clutch transmission technology that emanated from light vehicle, if you know, with Volkswagen, and we're applying that to the [indiscernible] trucks. So that's another very good example. Cooling -- thermal cooling technology, fans, fan drives, pump technology, cooling pumps, we apply those across both light and commercial vehicle. So yes, it's definitely. And as you think of the global situation, which where a lot of trucks, commercial trucks that is are getting smaller, think of like little delivery van-type technologies, and you think in some markets, light -- so-called light vehicles are getting bigger, large pickup truck-type vehicles and SUVs. There's a blend of technologies that comes together that can offer competitive position, and I think we do that actually very well.

componenttext: Just one question here. In the press release, you guys were talking about the Geely EC7-EV sedan and you kind of alludes you that it's design for emerging high-volume electric vehicle market. It's something a little bit of a change into your perception of the EV market. Is that really focused on growth and the push for any EVs in China? headline: BorgWarner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, I'll take that one. I see a couple of things. We -- obviously, we do see the EV market evolving. It's -- our macro perspective is we generally pointed to 2025 time line of about a couple of percent of the fleet. The world fleet would be EVs. We've a
componenttext: John, I'll take that one. I see a couple of things. We -- obviously, we do see the EV market evolving. It's -- our macro perspective is we generally pointed to 2025 time line of about a couple of percent of the fleet. The world fleet would be EVs. We've always said that could be 1%, 2% higher or a little lower, but in that range, 2%, 3% on them. We're not moving at this point away from that view, John. I would say incrementally, we'd see more energy, enthusiasm and intensity in China around electric vehicles. I would say the bigger message we're trying to get across, John, is this overhang with EVs, BorgWarner doesn't have anything. It's simply not true, and that's kind of what we're trying to articulate that we will serve that market. And this is a great example of hard parts and assets that are going into electric vehicles, leveraging BorgWarner's technology, and it's in China, and it's a reasonable volume, whether it's 15,000 this year. So macro, not really change on EV, John, 2%, 3% likely in the future. China probably getting incremental a little more aggressive that way. But the key message is BorgWarner is going to be in that space and play.
